channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Afghan earthquake: At least 1,000 people killed and 1,500 injured
item.description: The country's deadliest quake in two decades strikes in the night as many people sleep in their beds.

item.title: Polio virus detected in London sewage samples
item.description: Health officials say parents should ensure their children have been vaccinated against the disease.

item.title: Rail strike: Thursday's walkout will go ahead, says the RMT union
item.description: The RMT accuses Transport Secretary Grant Shapps of "wrecking" talks as it confirms the walkout.

item.title: Europe told to prepare for Russia turning off gas
item.description: The International Energy Agency warns that Russia may stop supplying gas to Europe this winter.

item.title: UK inflation rises at fastest rate for 40 years as food costs jump
item.description: Food, energy and fuel price rises help drive inflation up in May at its fastest pace since 1982.

item.title: Windrush Day: Queen praises pioneers as Waterloo statue unveiled
item.description: The monarch says she hopes the monument will "inspire present and future generations".

item.title: Kate Bush says the 'world has gone mad' over Stranger Things song
item.description: The singer gives a rare interview after going to number one thanks to the hit show Stranger Things.

item.title: Half Russian separatist force dead or wounded - UK
item.description: UK military intelligence believes the Donetsk militia in occupied Ukraine has lost 55% of its force.

item.title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak defends likely pensions rise
item.description: There's criticism of the move as ministers warn workers not to expect pay rises to match increasing costs.

item.title: Rotherham abuse scandal: Operation Linden report 'lets victims down'
item.description: A long-awaited report into police failings is criticised by a woman raped by grooming gangs in the town.

item.title: Bristol slavery victims recount 'horrendous' abuse
item.description: Maros Tancos and Joanna Gomulska tricked people into coming into the UK and then used them as slaves.

item.title: Victims abused by referee Hugh Stevenson say the SFA is blocking justice
item.description: Peter Haynes and Stuart McMillan say the SFA is refusing to accept any liability for what happened to them.

item.title: The tiny mites that have sex on our faces have a problem
item.description: The 0.3mm long organisms live deep in the pores of our faces but may be about to go extinct.

item.title: Bulldozer crushes 100 seized vehicles in New York
item.description: It is illegal to ride dirt bikes and ATVs (all-terrain vehicles) on the US city's streets.

item.title: Upskirt photos shared in Facebook groups, BBC finds
item.description: Meta says it has removed accounts and groups showing upskirting, after a BBC investigation.

item.title: Joe Lycett: PSNI received complaint after joke at Belfast show
item.description: Police in Northern Ireland received a complaint about a joke the stand-up made at a show this month.

item.title: Glastonbury Festival welcomes back crowds as fans deal with travel disruption
item.description: Worthy Farm will welcome more than 200,000 festival-goers, but some have had to change their plans.

item.title: The 100-year-old Edinburgh man still working three days a week
item.description: David Flucker, who recently celebrated his 100th birthday, volunteers in an Edinburgh charity shop.

item.title: Ice cream and amusements at the seaside
item.description: Jon Pountney's photographs of the Welsh seaside resorts on show in Cardiff.

item.title: 'It takes two clicks to set up a business, so act on your idea'
item.description: CEO Secrets: Tej Lalvani, boss of Vitabiotics and former Dragons' Den star, shares his advice.

item.title: Ed Sheeran lookalike mobbed at Ed Sheeran's Manchester gig
item.description: Wes Byrne was upgraded to the posh seats after being mobbed by Ed Sheeran's fans at one of his gigs.

item.title: Which trains are running this week?
item.description: Railway workers are on strike over pay and conditions.

item.title: The Glasgow vegan who teamed up with Kourtney Kardashian
item.description: Four years after Ross Mackay set up his company in Glasgow, he is working with Kourtney Kardashian.

item.title: Ukraine war: 'My kids cried every night asking if we're going to die'
item.description: Kateryna and her two sons are among 60 families in a camp set up for Ukrainian refugees fleeing war.

item.title: Romelu Lukaku: What went wrong for striker at Chelsea?
item.description: Romelu Lukaku was supposed to elevate Chelsea to title contenders, but returns to Inter Milan just 10 months after his £97.5m arrival - so what went wrong for the striker at the Blues?

item.title: Train strikes: Why railway workers say they are going on strike
item.description: Railway workers are striking over over cuts to jobs, conditions, pay and pensions.

item.title: Ukraine: Could it join the EU, and how might Russia react?
item.description: Ukraine hopes to become an official candidate for European Union (EU) membership.

item.title: Train strikes: How did passengers cope with day one?
item.description: As services ground to a halt, figures suggest commuters turned to bikes, taxis or decided to work from home.

item.title: Just Stop Oil: Activists says they have 'a duty to protest'
item.description: Newsbeat has been finding out about the individuals involved in the divisive climate action group.

item.title: Is Dominic Raab's quest to reform human rights law almost over?
item.description: The deputy PM says a British Bill of Rights will keep people safer, but it faces angry opposition.

item.title: Gareth Bale: Wales captain's representatives hold talks with Cardiff City
item.description: Cardiff City have held talks with Gareth Bale's representatives as they step up their efforts to sign the out-of-contract Wales captain.

item.title: Eastbourne: Best shots as Katie Boulter beats Karolina Pliskova
item.description: Watch the best shots as Britain's Katie Boulter records the "biggest win of her career" with a 1-6 6-4 6-4 win over world number seven Karolina Pliskova at Eastbourne.

item.title: Sadio Mane: Bayern Munich sign Senegal forward from Liverpool in £35m deal
item.description: Sadio Mane completes a £35m move from Liverpool to Bayern Munich on a three-year contract.

item.title: England in Netherlands: Jason Roy's century leads England to victory in third ODI
item.description: Jason Roy hammers 101 off 86 balls and Jos Buttler blasts 86 off 64 to help England clinch a comfortable eight-wicket victory over the Netherlands.

item.title: What is the UK's inflation rate and why is the cost of living going up?
item.description: UK inflation is rising at 9.1%, its fastest rate for 40 years, and could go even higher.

item.title: Asda says some shoppers asking cashiers to stop at £30
item.description: Rising food prices are sparking a "massive change in behaviour", the supermarket's chairman tells the BBC.

item.title: Three things we're cutting back on as prices rise
item.description: People in Birmingham and Kent tell the BBC how they are cutting back to cope with the cost of living crisis.

item.title: 'Queues down the street' in Stoke for free supermarket food
item.description: Nikki Barrett runs Affordable Food Stoke, which saves surplus food and gives it away for free.

item.title: Would you walk to another shop to save 5p on oranges?
item.description: Single mum Safina has taken an extreme approach to saving money since her events business collapsed.

item.title: Five tips for saving petrol money examined
item.description: With filling up an average car now costing £100, are drivers doing the right things to save money?

item.title: People cut back on food, fuel and clothes as prices rise, BBC survey suggests
item.description: More than eight in 10 people say they are worried about the cost-of-living, a BBC survey suggests.

item.title: Food bills are set to soar by £380 this year
item.description: As grocery prices rise at their highest pace in 13 years, experts warn there are more hikes to come.
